Executive Summary [?68.155]

The owner or operator shall provide in the RMP an executive summary that includes a brief description of the following elements: (a) The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at the stationary source; (b) The stationary source and regulated substances handled; (c) The worst-case release scenario(s) and the alternative release scenario(s), including administrative controls and mitigation measures to limit the distances for each reported scenario;(d) The general accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps; (e) The five-year accident history; (f) The emergency response program; and (g) Planned changes to improve safety.

This is the first Risk Management Plan for the West Edinburg Water Treatment Plant, which went into service on July 23, 2008, the day Hurricane Dolly made landfall in the area. The Edinburg Water Filtration Plant lost power and the newly constructed West Edinburg Water Treatment Plant began producing treated water. The West Edinburg Water Treatment Plant policy approach to accidental release prevention integrates technology, procedures, and good management practices. The Edinburg emergency response policy involves the preparation of a response plan tailored to each of its facilities and to the emergency response services available in the community. The policy adheres to United States Environmental Protection Agency (USEPA) Prevention Program procedures where applicable, and complies with USEPA Emergency Response Program requirements.

Antonio Leal, Water Plant Superintendent, is the responsible official at the Edinburg West Edinburg Water Treatment Plant. The plant operates on property just west of the Edinburg water storage reservoirs at 1752 South Mon Mack Road, Edinburg, Hidalgo County, Texas. Its chlorination building sits on the east side of the plant and consists of an enclosed room that houses nine (9), 1-ton Chlorine cylinders. The chlorine room is equipped wi

th a leak detector, alarm, fans, a drain, and a scrubber. Personnel oversee the facility 24-hours a day, including daily inspections of the chlorine building. The facility houses emergency air and power supply. Self-Contained-Breathing-Apparatus (SCBA) storage occupies a location at the entrance to the chlorine building, approximately 50 feet from the chlorination room.

The offsite consequence analysis for the West Edinburg Water Treatment Plant includes consideration of two release scenarios for each parameter of concern (chlorine): 
1. A Worst-Case Release
2. An Alternative Scenario
The EPA guidelines define AWorst-Case Release@ resulting from an unspecified failure in which, AThe owner-operator shall assume that the...maximum quantity in the largest vessel...is released as a gas over 10 minutes.@ The same guidelines define an AAlternative Scenario@ as, AMore likely to occur than the worst-case release scenario.@

Performance of atmospheric dispersion modeling determines the distance traveled by a parameter of concern before its concentration decreases to the Atoxic endpoint@. The EPA defines Atoxic endpoint@ as 0.0087 mg/L for chlorine. This value corresponds to the Emergency Response Planning Guidelines Level 2 (ERPG-2) concentrations, which the American Industrial Hygiene Association (AIHA) defines as:

AThe maximum airborne concentration below which it is believed that nearly all individuals could be exposed for up to one-hour without experiencing or developing irreversible or other serious health effects or symptoms that could impair an individual?s ability to take protection action.@

The estimated population potentially affected by the release equals the residential population within the radius of a circle corresponding to the toxic endpoint distance.
